Free AI Website Builders What's Actually Free

Looking for a free AI website builder? Most "free" plans are barely usable. Here's what you actually get for free, and what you'll have to pay for.

The reality: Every AI website builder offers a "free" plan. Most are unusable for anything real. Limited pages, huge watermarks, no custom domain, capped bandwidth. They're not free products—they're trials designed to push you to paid plans.

What "free" actually means

AI website builders are businesses, not charities. Their free plans exist to get you hooked, not to serve you long-term. Here's what free plans typically include:

  • Page limits: 1-3 pages max. Enough for a landing page, not a real site.
  • Branding: "Built with [Tool]" watermarks or badges. Looks unprofessional.
  • Domains: ugly subdomain like yoursite.framer.ai or yoursite.durable.co
  • Bandwidth: capped visitors or storage. Hit the limit and your site goes down.
  • Features: No export, no advanced features, limited AI generations.

This is by design. They want free plans to be just good enough to try, too limited to use seriously.

Framer: Generous but still limited

Framer's free plan is one of the better ones, but still has significant limitations.

What you get for free

Unlimited pages (surprisingly generous). Full design editor. AI generation. Publishing on framer.ai subdomain. TLS certificate included.

This means you can build a complete site and launch it publicly without paying. For testing or personal projects, this is actually usable.

What's locked behind paywall

Custom domain requires paid plan ($15/month minimum). That's the big one—you can't use your own .com without paying.

Export also requires $25/month plan. No way to get your code out on free.

CMS features (blogs, collections) are paid-only. So is removing Framer branding.

Real example: Portfolio site

Designer used Framer free plan to build portfolio. Published to name.framer.ai. Looked professional, worked fine. Used it for 6 months while job hunting.

Once hired, needed proper domain. Paid $15/month. Free plan was great for testing, not for long-term branding.

Durable: 14-day trial, not free

Durable advertises "free" but it's a 14-day trial. That's it.

What you get for "free"

Full access for 14 days. AI generation, editing, publishing. Everything works.

But after 14 days, your site either goes offline or you start paying. There's no permanent free tier.

What happens after trial

Pay $12/month minimum or lose your site. No migration path. No export. Either pay or rebuild elsewhere.

This is the most aggressive freemium model I tested. Great for trying, terrible for long-term free use.

Real example: Weekend project

Entrepreneur used Durable trial to test business idea. Generated landing page, got 200 visitors over weekend, validated concept.

Then had to either pay $12/month or rebuild. Chose to rebuild in WordPress. Trial was perfect for validation, useless for ongoing free use.

10Web: Limited but usable

10Web's free plan is restricted but functional for simple sites.

What you get for free

1 website. 10 pages. 1GB storage. AI generation included. 10Web subdomain.

This is enough for a simple site—landing page, about, contact. But hit 10 pages and you're paying.

What's locked behind paywall

Custom domain requires paid plan ($10/month minimum). More than 10 pages requires upgrade. More storage requires upgrade.

But since it's WordPress, you can export your content easily. Moving to self-hosted WordPress is straightforward.

Real example: Simple local business

Local bakery used 10Web free plan for website. Homepage, menu, contact. 6 pages total. Published to 10web subdomain.

Worked fine for 8 months. Eventually needed custom domain for branding. Paid $10/month. Free tier was genuinely usable, just limited.

Relume: Generous free tier

Relume's free plan is actually useful, but remember—it's not a website builder.

What you get for free

3 projects. Full sitemap generation. Full wireframe generation. Export to Figma/Framer/Webflow.

This is enough for real work. You can plan multiple sites, export wireframes, build elsewhere. No time limit.

What's locked behind paywall

More than 3 projects requires $20/month. But unlimited projects is the only real limitation—features are the same.

If you only work on 1-2 sites at a time, free plan is all you need.

Real example: Agency workflow

Design agency uses Relume free tier for client projects. Plan sitemap and wireframes for client A, export, build in Framer. Once live, archive that project, start client B.

They've never hit the 3-project limit because they archive completed work. Free tier is indefinitely usable.

The truly free alternatives

If you actually need free forever, AI website builders aren't the answer. Here's what is:

Static site generators + free hosting

Cost: $0-30/year total.

Astro, Hugo, or Eleventy for site generation. GitHub Pages, Netlify, or Vercel for hosting. Custom domain costs $10-15/year.

No AI generation, but genuinely free. Total cost is just domain registration. Fast, secure, scalable. This is what I use.

WordPress.com free tier

Cost: $0 forever, with limitations.

3GB storage. WordPress subdomain. Limited themes. No plugins. But it's genuinely free and doesn't expire.

Usable for simple blogs. Not for serious sites due to limitations, but it won't suddenly cost money.

Google Sites

Cost: $0.

Basic sites only. No e-commerce. Limited design. But it's free, unlimited, and won't expire. Good for internal docs, simple portfolios, not much else.

The hidden costs of "free"

Even when the plan is free, there are costs:

  • Time: Free plans are often slower, have fewer features, require workarounds.
  • Professionalism: Subdomains and watermarks look unprofessional. Lost credibility costs money.
  • Lock-in: No export means rebuilding later. Time = money.
  • Migration: Moving from free to paid is easy. Moving from free to elsewhere is hard.

"Free" has opportunity costs. Sometimes paying $15/month saves hours of work.

Decision framework

When should you use free plans vs paying?

Use free plans when:

  • You're testing or learning
  • You don't care about custom domain yet
  • You're validating a business idea
  • It's a personal project with no revenue
  • You need something temporary

Pay for a plan when:

  • You need a custom domain for branding
  • You're using this for a real business
  • You need features locked behind paywall
  • You want to remove watermarks/branding
  • You're generating revenue from the site

Skip AI builders entirely when:

  • You want truly free, not freemium
  • You're willing to learn Hugo/Astro
  • You care about performance and control
  • You don't need AI generation

Bottom line

Free AI website builders exist, but they're limited by design. Framer and Relume have the best free tiers—genuinely usable for small projects. Durable is just a trial. 10Web is functional but constrained.

If you need truly free forever, skip AI builders and use static site generators. If you're okay paying eventually, start with free tiers to test, then upgrade when you hit limitations.

Just don't expect "free" to mean "unlimited." These are businesses, not charities.
